Comment: The way to achieve uniformity is for judges to follow appellate level precedents.   You can't have trial courts actively defer cases to appellate courts for a variety of reasons. It means appellate courts won't control their own dockets and will be overburdened with cases, it means appellate courts will have to hear full trials with evidence and witnesses, which makes them take even longer, and you no longer have injunctions available at first instance where they need to be available because litigants need quicker decisions.   So basically the point of even having all the district courts is to give people access to justice in the first place, and the circuits are mainly supposed to be there to reverse errors and impose uniformity when the district courts seem to be diverging.   None of this changes the fact that if a court has decided the government can't do something, then the government still can't do that thing (subject to appeal) even on the other side of the same country where the law is the same
